title: R Coding Workshop
text:
Variables
<-: initialize a variable and assign a value

# variable_name <- variable_value
x <- 1984
y <- "World Geodetic System"





R variable naming

title: R Coding Workshop
text:
R Data Types class()



“numeric”

double
integer

“character”
“logical”



print(class(x))

[1] "numeric"

print(class(y))

[1] "character"

z <- class(x) == class(y)
print(class(z))

[1] "logical"







Operators and Logical Operators
Type Casting

title: R Coding Workshop
text:
R Data Structures

Vector
Matrix
Array
Factor
List
Data Frame

title: R Coding Workshop
text:
Starting with Vectors


Ways to create a vector

c()
seq(from, to, by)
:



v1 <- c(
    "Bryce Canyon", "Canyonlands", "Arches", "Zion", "Capitol Reef"
    )
v2 <- 1:5
v2

[1] 1 2 3 4 5



v3 <- seq(21.9, 25.3, 0.1)
is.vector(v2)

[1] TRUE

title: R Coding Workshop
text:
Subsetting a Vector

Indexing


# v1 <- c(
    # "Bryce Canyon", "Canyonlands", "Arches", "Zion", "Capitol Reef"
    # )
v1[1]

[1] "Bryce Canyon"

v1[-1]

[1] "Canyonlands"  "Arches"       "Zion"         "Capitol Reef"



Subsetting using Logical Vectors


v4 <- 1:12
bool_v4 <- v4 > 8
v4[bool_v4]

[1]  9 10 11 12



Access by name


names(v4) <- month.abb
v4["Jan"]

Jan 
  1

title: R Coding Workshop
text:
Data Frame objects

Thinking of data.frame as a collection of column vectors

Ways to create a df

mth_df <- data.frame(
    mth = 1:12,
    mth_str = month.abb
)
mth_df

   mth mth_str
1    1     Jan
2    2     Feb
3    3     Mar
4    4     Apr
5    5     May
6    6     Jun
7    7     Jul
8    8     Aug
9    9     Sep
10  10     Oct
11  11     Nov
12  12     Dec



mth_df |> class()

[1] "data.frame"






import external tabular dataset

title: R Coding Workshop
text:
Subsetting data.frame

print(utah_df[, 1])

[1] "Bryce Canyon" "Canyonlands"  "Arches"       "Zion"         "Capitol Reef"

print(utah_df[1, ])

  national_park      lat       lon
1  Bryce Canyon 37.64062 -112.1696

print(utah_df$national_park)

[1] "Bryce Canyon" "Canyonlands"  "Arches"       "Zion"         "Capitol Reef"

utah_df[["national_park"]]

[1] "Bryce Canyon" "Canyonlands"  "Arches"       "Zion"         "Capitol Reef"

title: R Coding Workshop
text:
R List

A vector that allows to have elements of different data type
Nested


summary(utah_df)

 national_park           lat             lon        
 Length:5           Min.   :37.20   Min.   :-113.0  
 Class :character   1st Qu.:37.64   1st Qu.:-112.2  
 Mode  :character   Median :38.29   Median :-111.3  
                    Mean   :38.05   Mean   :-111.2  
                    3rd Qu.:38.48   3rd Qu.:-109.8  
                    Max.   :38.62   Max.   :-109.6  



class(utah_df[1])

[1] "data.frame"

title: R Coding Workshop
section: Getting to sf and a map
text:
Getting to sf and a map

library(sf)
library(mapview)
utah_sf <- st_as_sf(
    utah_df,
    coords = c('lon', 'lat'),
    crs = 4326
)
utah_sf |> mapview()






utah_sf

Simple feature collection with 5 features and 1 field
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: -112.987 ymin: 37.20027 xmax: -109.6198 ymax: 38.61676
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
  national_park                   geometry
1  Bryce Canyon POINT (-112.1696 37.64062)
2   Canyonlands POINT (-109.8252 38.47878)
3        Arches POINT (-109.6198 38.61676)
4          Zion  POINT (-112.987 37.20027)
5  Capitol Reef  POINT (-111.2619 38.2916)






prelude to factor class: How were the points colored? Why are we having a legend on the map?

How to avoid presenting this map

title: Taman
text:
In winter, when night’s shade
possesses longer half the world,
and longer in the idle stillness,
by the bemisted moon,
the lazy orient sleeps,
awakened at her customary hour
she would get up by candles.
